div.p: The Government of Canada's relationships with its provinces and territories are very important.
I’m 37, Bachelor in Environmental Studies, born in Toronto,
living in Edmonton working for Natural Resources Canada, and loving it.
So you’re asking me what I do: good question.
I think the best description is that I solve puzzles,
but the puzzles have to do with people and organizations and policy.
And one of the coolest files I am working on relates to a Memorandum of Understanding
between the Government of Canada and the Government of Alberta,
about collaboration on safety and efficiency of resource extraction,
which as you can imagine, is a key activity in this region.
You see, in the field of clean energy there’s overlap between federal and provincial responsibilities
and that means we need to partner and collaborate effectively
to make it work smoothly, and, of course, to get results for Canadians.
Lately, I have been working on organizing a meeting with a team from Innovation Alberta
and science reps from NRCan to get going on work that focuses on cleaner energy.
So on this file, my team is acting as a bridge that connects the provincial team
from the Government of Alberta and NRCAN science and policy people for the first time.
It’s really interesting because we work in different organizations with different mandates,
but we get to work together on similar objectives,
creating unique partnerships between people and between organizations, too.
So – pulling it together: I coordinated a day and time with everyone,
and then set up a videoconference and a solid agenda –
making sure that everyone had what they’d need for a productive meeting.
Now, these meetings are important forums for us to collaborate
on shared areas of federal and provincial responsibilities.
And since these relationships are important in achieving desired outcomes,
you can bet that it’s critical to do everything we can to strengthen these partnerships.
It’s a real… “meeting of the minds.”
So, why take all this care about a single meeting?
Well, because it’s… unchartered territory… and how this first meeting relating to the MOU goes
will really drive the rest of the partnership going forward.
What am I learning?
I’m learning about the importance of federal and provincial collaboration on government priorities.
And I’m learning about bringing people together and making it all work, which is fascinating.
And, of course, at the end of the day, what we do, both at the federal and provincial level,
is all about working to serve Canadians…
which is very satisfying.
